Indeed, warn them of the Day of Regret [yawm al-hasra], when the matter is decreed, while they are in heedlessness [ghafla] and they do not believe. And by my life, the allusion here is to the Day of Resurrection [yawm al-qiyamah], but it is in pre-eternity [azal]. However, on the Day of Resurrection, what was decreed by the preordainment [qada'] becomes manifest. So wonder at yourself, how you laugh and play and busy yourself with the trivialities of the world [dunya], and you do not know what the decree has preceded with concerning your right. If you say, "Would that I knew what my destination is, and to what my end and return will be, and what the decree has preceded with concerning my right," then for you is a sign [â€˜alamah] by which you may find comfort and affirm your hope because of it. And it is that you look at your states [ahwal] and your deeds [a'mal]. For everyone is facilitated for what he was created. So if the path of good [khayr] has been made easy for you, then give glad tidings, for you are kept far from the Fire. And if you do not intend any good except that obstacles surround you and repel it, and you do not intend any evil [sharr] except that its causes are made easy for you, then know that it is decreed against you. For the indication of this upon the outcome [â€˜aqibah] is like the indication of rain upon plants and the indication of smoke upon fire. Indeed, Allah, the Exalted, has said: "Indeed, the righteous [al-abrar] are in bliss, and indeed, the wicked [al-fujjar] are in a Blazing Fire." So present yourself against these two verses, and you have come to know your abode [mustaqarr] in the two abodes [al-darayn]. And Allah knows best.

And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, truthfulness [al-sidq] guides to righteousness [al-birr], and righteousness guides to Paradise. And verily, a man will be truthful until he is recorded with Allah as a truthful one [siddiq]. And indeed, falsehood [al-kidhb] guides to wickedness [al-fujur], and wickedness guides to the Fire. And verily, a man will lie until he is recorded with Allah as a liar [kadhdhab]." And it suffices in the virtue of truthfulness [al-sidq] that 'the truthful one' [al-siddiq] is derived from it. And Allah the Exalted described the Prophets with it in the context of praise and commendation, saying: "And mention in the Book, Abraham. Indeed, he was a truthful one [siddiqan], a prophet."

Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
Indeed, they argued with His saying, the Most High, narrating from Ibrahim, peace be upon him: "And I shall withdraw from you and what you call upon besides Allah, and I shall call upon my Lord..." [19:48]. Then He, the Most High, said: "So when he withdrew from them and what they worshipped besides Allah, We bestowed upon him Ishaq and Ya'qub, and each We made a prophet." This is an indication that this was by the blessing [baraka] of withdrawal [al-'uzla]. And this is weak, for mixing with the disbelievers [al-kuffar] has no benefit in it except calling them to the religion [al-din], and when there is despair of their answering, then there is no recourse except to abandon them. The discourse, rather, is concerning mixing with the Muslims [al-Muslimin] and what is in it of blessing [baraka].

Indeed, the verse of the Almighty: **"On the Day We will gather the righteous to the Most Merciful as honored guests"** [19:85], and His saying: **"And there is none of you except he will come to it"** [19:71], and His saying: **"Do whatever you will"** [41:40], and His saying: **"Whoever desires the harvest of the Hereafter, We increase for him in his harvest"** [42:20], and His saying: **"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it"** [99:7-8], and His saying: **"And We will proceed to what they have done of deeds"** [46:28], and likewise His saying: **"By time, Indeed, mankind is in loss"** [103:1-3] to the end of the surahâ€”these are four conditions for salvation from loss. The fear of the prophets, despite the abundant blessings [ni`am] bestowed upon them, was because they did not feel secure from the plan [makr] of God Almightyâ€”**"And none feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people"** [7:99]. It is even narrated that the Prophet and Gabriel, peace be upon them both, wept out of fear of God Almighty, so God revealed to them: "Why do you weep when I have granted you security?" They said, "And who can feel secure from Your plan?" It was as if, since they knew that God is the Knower of the unseen [ghuyub] and that they had no grasp of the ultimate ends of matters, they did not feel secure that His statement "I have granted you security" might be a trial [ibtila'] and a test [imtihan] for them, and a plan [makr] against them. So much so that if their fear had subsided, it would have become apparent that they had felt secure from the plan and had not been true to their statement. Just as Abraham, peace be upon him, when placed in the catapult, said, **"Sufficient for me is Allah"** [9:129], and this was among the greatest supplications, he was tested and confronted by Gabriel in the air until he said, "Do you have any need?" He replied, "As for from you, no." That was being true to the reality of his statement, "Sufficient for me is Allah." So God Almighty informed about him, saying, **"And [mention] Abraham, who fulfilled [waffa]"** [53:37]â€”meaning, he fulfilled the requirement of his statement "Sufficient for me is Allah." And with the like of this, He informed about Moses, peace be upon him, where He said: **"Indeed, we fear that he will hasten [punishment] against us or that he will transgress." He said, "Fear not. Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see."** [20:45-46] And despite this, when the magicians threw their magic, Moses felt fear within himself, for he did not feel secure from the plan [makr] of God, and the matter became confused for him until security was renewed for him and it was said to him, **"Fear not. Indeed, it is you who are superior."** [20:68] And when the strength of the Muslims weakened on the day of Badr, he, peace be upon him, said, "O Allah, if You destroy this band, there will remain no one on the face of the earth who worships You." So Abu Bakr, may God be pleased with him, said, "Leave off your pleading with your Lord, for He will be true to you with what He promised you." So the station [maqam] of Al-Siddiq, may God be pleased with him, was the station of trust [thiqah] in the promise of God, and the station of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was the station of fear [khawf] from the plan [makr] of Godâ€”and it is more complete, for it only issues from perfect knowledge [ma`rifah] of the secrets [asrar] of God Almighty and the hidden realities [khafaaya] of His actions and the meanings of His attributes, some of what issues from them being expressed as 'plan' [makr]. And no human has the ability to grasp the essence [kunh] of the attributes of God Almighty. Whoever knows the reality of knowledge [ma`rifah]â€”the deficiency of his knowledge from encompassing the essence [kunh] of mattersâ€”his fear inevitably becomes great. And for that reason, Jesus, peace be upon him, said when it was said to him: **"Did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?'" He said, "Exalted are You! It is not for me to say that to which I have no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself."** [5:116] And he said: **"If You punish them - indeed they are Your servants; but if You forgive them..."** [5:118] the verse. He referred the matter entirely to the Will [mashiyyah] and removed himself completely from the affair, knowing that he had no part in the command and that matters are tied to the Will with a connection that is beyond the limits of rational conceptions and customary norms, so they cannot be judged by analogy [qiyas], conjecture [hads], or calculation [hisaban], let alone by verification [tahqiq] and certainty [istiqan]. This is what has severed the hearts [qulub] of the knowers [`arifun], for the greatest calamity [tammah] is the connection of your affair to the Will of One who does not care about you. If He destroys you, He has destroyed your like from those who cannot be counted, and He has continually, in the world [dunya], been punishing them with various pains and illnesses, and sickening their hearts [qulub] with disbelief [kufr] and hypocrisy [nifaq], then making the punishment eternal upon them forever. Then He informs about Himself and says: **"And if We had willed, We could have given every soul its guidance, but the word from Me will come true, 'I will surely fill Hell with jinn and mankind all together.'"** [32:13] And the Almighty said: **"And the word of your Lord has been fulfilled: 'I will surely fill Hell...'"** [11:119] the verse. So how can one not fear what has been decreed of the word from eternity [azal], and how can one hope to avert it? If the matter were otherwise, hopes would extend to finding a stratagem for it, but there is nothing except submission [taslim] in it, and deducing the hidden precedent [sabiqah] from the apparent, manifest causes [asbab] upon the heart [qalb] and the limbs. So whoever is facilitated the causes [asbab] of evil and is barred from the causes [asbab] of good, and his connection to the world [dunya] is firmly established, it is as if the secret [sirr] of the precedent [sabiqah] that preceded for him with wretchedness [shaqawah] has been truly unveiled to him, for **"everyone is facilitated for what he was created for"** [Hadith]. And if all good deeds are facilitated, and the heart [qalb] is completely detached from the world [dunya], and with its outward and inward turned towards God, this would necessitate a lessening of fearâ€”if constancy [dawam] upon that could be trusted. But the danger of the ending [khatimah] and the difficulty of steadfastness [thabat] increase the flames of fear, igniting them and preventing them from being extinguished. And how can one feel secure from a change of state when **"the heart [qalb] of the believer is between two fingers of the fingers of the Most Merciful"** [Hadith], and the heart [qalb] is more fluctuating [taqallub] than a pot when it is boiling? And the Turner of the hearts [muqallib al-qulub], Glory be to Him, has said: **"Indeed, the punishment of their Lord is not that from which one is safe."** [70:28] So the most ignorant of people is he who feels secure from Him while He calls out with warning against feeling secure [amn]. And if God had not been gentle with His knowing servants [ibad al-`arifin], soothing the spirits of their hearts [arwah qulubihim] with the spirit of hope [ruh al-raja'], their hearts [qulub] would have been burned by the fire of fear [nar al-khawf]. So the causes [asbab] of hope [raja'] are a mercy [rahmat] for the elect of God, and the causes [asbab] of heedlessness [ghaflah] are a mercy [rahmat] upon the commonality of creation in a sense, for if the covering [ghita'] were lifted, the souls [nufus] would expire and the hearts [qulub] would be severed from fear of the Turner of the hearts [muqallib al-qulub]. One of the knowers [al-`arifun] said: "If there were a pillar fifty years between me and one I knew to be a monotheist [muwahhid], and he died, I would not affirm for him monotheism [tawhid], for I do not know what fluctuation [taqallub] appeared to him." And another said: "If testimony [shahadah] were at the door of the house and death upon Islam were at the door of the room, I would choose death upon Islam, for I do not know what might occur to my heart [qalb] between the door of the room and the door of the house." And Abu Al-Darda' would swear by God that no one feels secure about his faith [iman] that it will not be stripped from him before death except that it is stripped. And Sahl would say: "The fear of the truthful ones [siddiqin] from a bad ending [su' al-khatimah] is with every thought [khatrah] and with every movement, and they are those whom God Almighty described when He said: **'And their hearts [qulub] are fearful [wajilah]'** [23:60]." And when Sufyan was near death, he began to weep and show distress. It was said to him, "O Abu Abdullah, have hope [raja'], for the pardon of God is greater than your sins." He said, "Is it over my sins that I weep? If I knew that I would die upon monotheism [tawhid], I would not care if I met God with sins like mountains." And it is related from one of the fearful ones [al-kha'ifin] that he instructed one of his brothers, saying: "When my death approaches, sit at my head. If you see me die upon monotheism [tawhid], then take all that I own, buy almonds and sugar, and scatter them for the children of the town, and say, 'This is the wedding feast of the one who escaped.' And if I die upon other than monotheism [tawhid], then inform the people of that so they are not deceived by attending my funeral, so that only those who wish may attend my funeral with clear insight [basirah], lest hypocrisy [riya'] attaches to me after death." He said, "And how will I know that?" So he mentioned a sign to him. And he saw the sign of monotheism [tawhid] at his death, so he bought the sugar and almonds and distributed them. And Sahl would say: "The seeker [murid] fears that he will be afflicted with disobedience [ma`asi], and the knower [`arif] fears that he will be afflicted with disbelief [kufr]." And Abu Zayd would say: "When I head to the mosque, it is as if there is a girdle [zunnar] around my waistâ€”I fear it will take me to the church and the house of fireâ€”until I enter the mosque, then the girdle is cut from me. And this is for me five times every day." And it is related from Jesus, peace be upon him, that he said: "O company of disciples, you fear disobedience [ma`asi], and we, the company of prophets, fear disbelief [kufr]." And it is related in the stories of the prophets that a prophet complained to God Almighty of hunger, lice, and nakedness for years, and his garment was wool. So God Almighty revealed to him: "My servant, are you not content that I have protected your heart [qalb] from disbelieving in Me, that you ask Me for the world [dunya]?" So he took dust and placed it on his head and said, "Yes, I am content, O my Lord, so protect me from disbelief [kufr]." So if the fear of the knowers [al-`arifin], with the firmness of their feet and the strength of their faith [iman], is from a bad ending [su' al-khatimah], then how can the weak not fear it? And a bad ending [su' al-khatimah] has causes [asbab] that precede death, like innovation [bid`ah], hypocrisy [nifaq], arrogance [kibr], and a host of blameworthy traits. And for that reason, the fear of the Companions from hypocrisy [nifaq] intensified, to the point that Al-Hasan said: "If I knew I was free from hypocrisy [nifaq], it would be more beloved to me than all that the sun has risen upon." And they did not mean the hypocrisy [nifaq] that is the opposite of the foundation of faith [iman], but rather what gathers with the foundation of faith [iman], so that one is a Muslim and a hypocrite [munafiq]. And it has many signs. He, peace be upon him, said: **"Four traits, whoever has them is a pure hypocrite [munafiq], even if he prays and fasts and claims he is a Muslim. And if there is in him one trait of them, then in him is a branch of hypocrisy [nifaq] until he leaves it: when he speaks, he lies; when he promises, he breaks it; when he is entrusted, he betrays; and when he disputes, he acts immorally."** And in another wording: **"And when he makes a covenant, he betrays."** And the Companions and the Followers interpreted hypocrisy [nifaq] with interpretations that none is free from except a truthful one [siddiq]. For Al-Hasan said: "Indeed, from hypocrisy [nifaq] is the difference between the secret [sirr] and the public [`alaniyah], the difference between the tongue [lisan] and the heart [qalb], and the difference between the entrance [madhul] and the exit [makhraj]." And who is free from these meanings? Rather, these matters have become familiar and customary among people, and they have forgotten that they are utterly reprehensible. Indeed, this occurred close to the time of prophethood, so what is the assumption about our time? To the point that Hudhayfah, may God be pleased with him, said: "Indeed, a man would speak a word during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and would thereby become a hypocrite [munafiq]. Indeed, I hear it from one of you ten times a day." And the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, would say: "Indeed, you perform deeds that are finer in your eyes than a hair, but we used to count them during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, among the major sins." And one of them said: "The sign of hypocrisy [nifaq] is that you dislike from people what you do the like of, and that you love for something of injustice, and that you hate for something of truth." And it was said: From hypocrisy [nifaq] is that when he is praised for something not in him, it pleases him. And a man said to Ibn `Umar, may God have mercy on him: "Indeed, we enter upon these rulers and we affirm them in what they say, but when we leave, we speak about them." He said: "We used to count this hypocrisy [nifaq] during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." And it is related that he heard a man reviling Al-Hajjaj and attacking him, so he said: "What do you thinkâ€”if Al-Hajjaj were present, would you speak as you have spoken?" He said, "No." He said, "We used to count this hypocrisy [nifaq] during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." And more severe than that is what is related: A group sat at the door of Hudhayfah waiting for him, and they were speaking about something concerning him. When he came out to them, they fell silent out of shyness from him. He said, "Speak about what you were saying." So they were silent. He said, "We used to count this hypocrisy [nifaq] during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." And this Hudhayfah had been specifically given knowledge of the hypocrites [munafiqun] and the causes [asbab] of hypocrisy [nifaq]. And he would say: "Indeed, there comes upon the heart [qalb] a moment when it is filled with faith [iman] until there is no room for hypocrisy [nifaq] in it the point of a needle, and there comes upon it a moment when it is filled with hypocrisy [nifaq] until there is no room for faith [iman] in it the point of a needle." So you have come to know by this that the fear of the knowers [al-`arifin] is from a bad ending [su' al-khatimah], and that its cause [sabab] is matters that precede it: among them is innovation [bid`ah]; among them is disobedience [ma`asi]; among them is hypocrisy [nifaq]. And when is a servant free from something from the totality of that? Even if he thinks he is free from it, that is hypocrisy [nifaq], for it is said: "Whoever feels secure from hypocrisy [nifaq] is a hypocrite [munafiq]." And they say, "The Most Merciful has taken [for Himself] a son."
You have done an atrocious thing.
The heavens almost rupture therefrom and the earth splits open and the mountains collapse in devastation
That they attribute to the Most Merciful a son.

There is no one in the heavens and earth but that he comes to the Most Merciful as a servant.
He has enumerated them and counted them a [full] counting.
And all of them are coming to Him on the Day of Resurrection alone.

So glory be to the One who is singular in subjugation and mastery, who has exclusively reserved for Himself the right to permanence [al-baqa'], and who has humbled all categories of creation through what He has decreed upon them of annihilation [al-fana']. Then He made death [al-mawt] a deliverance for the God-fearing [al-atqiya'] and an appointed time, in their right, for the meeting [al-liqa']. And He made the grave [al-qabr] a prison for the wretched [al-ashqiya'] and a constricted confinement for them until the Day of Separation and Decree.
